Row.Text: As the Shawnees gather, blue clouds of tobacco smoke rise, mingling with laughter and conversation.

The Prophet summons people from near and far to witness proof of the power invested in him by the Master of Life. Standing tall before the waiting crowds, Tecumseh reiterates the message witnessed in his brother's visions: change is coming, but through unity, all challenges will be overcome. Suddenly, as the Prophet foretold, the sky darkens and the sun disappears.
Word of this miracle must spread.

As enemy forces draw near, citizens prepare to flee. The Prophet's messengers convince the foes to settle nearby in preparation for peace talks. In this brief respite, Tecumseh weighs the promise of war with the advantages of peace.
Soldiers fall beneath the fury of Tecumseh's warriors. Now peace will reign, by Tecumseh's hand.
Bloodshed is not always the answer.
Rumors abound of witches and sorcerers threatening the very fabric of Tecumseh's society. The Prophet warns of their growing power, but there are other ways of dealing with dissenting voices.
The fear of witches wanes as the peoples' trust in Tecumseh grows. Now that their concerns are quelled, life becomes joyous once more.

Tecumseh addresses new neighbors with both fire and compassion. Their lands, he declares, are their own, and their customs as well. But to maintain both, there must be unity – and in unity, strength. The ears of young warriors perk up at his offer of glory, while their elders wonder whether this is truly the path to preservation.
The allegiance of the young promises a bright future.
Neighboring warriors gather in Tecumseh's settlements, ready to take on the world. As they raise their voices together, their songs combine into a single melody of unity.
Become Suzerain of an Independent Power.
The elders' doubts must be respected.

As the earth wages war on humanity, many fear that these disasters are signs of the Master of Life's rage. Those who once doubted the Prophet's teachings now become believers. Tecumseh welcomes these new adherents, then sends them out once more to share their discovery with the world.
Many prayers are more powerful than one. The Prophet guides believers across the world to appease the angry earth, and the earth listens.
Have 4 Settlements following your Founded Religion.

As farmers return from their fields, the Shawnees gather for the Bread Dance. Women lay cakes of corn next to meat from the hunters. Food grown and food gathered – life nurtured and life taken. The people dance, sing, and give thanks for the earth's bounty that keeps them fed and provides for their futures.
The forests are rich with game.

Animals have become rare in the wilderness, and Shawnee hunters wonder what has become of them. An eavesdropping old woman points to the forest. The trees are too dense, she tells them. If they want the animals to return, they must make the woods friendly.
The forest will be set alight.
Cutting some trees should do the job.

Shawnee citizens gather at the mawaskawe skote to discuss the rising population in the capital. Several chiefs worry that cultural diversity is on the decline as people's lives become more intertwined in dense neighborhoods.
Evolution should be left to its own devices.
The hoceepkileni readies his gear and his medicine bag. Many await his words and counsel. So do those who have not yet opened their eyes to the world's true nature.
The Shawnees will benefit from his wisdom.
Mourners sing to the body of the kispoko nena’to, remembering his brave stand and wondering when his death will be avenged. Suddenly a cry goes up: an enemy has fallen.
The warriors' whoops fill the air.

The drum beats as Shawnee warriors prepare for war. Gathering food and weapons, they begin their fast to purify themselves for the struggle on the horizon. A great clamor rises. The warriors whoop and fire their guns, dancing and singing to their future success. Then – silence, as they melt into the landscape in pursuit of foes.

Shawnee silversmiths are inundated with requests for new pieces. Rings and bracelets, earrings and plates… Everyone desires the beautiful metal, and soon each settlement shines brighter than the moon.
One can never have too much silver.
It is time to export these masterpieces.
Cities around the world clamor for Shawnee goods. Traders race from one market to the next, courting buyers and sharing stories of their home.
Shawnee warriors celebrate a successful hunt. Yet older men wonder if their young peers have properly given thanks for the sacrifices made for them by the animals.
Tradition must be preserved lest it be forgotten.
Grateful animals multiply and keep the forests full.

Crowds from near and far flock to the menagerie of the Shawnee. The animals are exquisite, and all marvel at these strange beasts. Yet amid the extraordinary struts a single reminder of the ordinary – a turkey, long revered by the people and necessary to their way of life.
All animals are equal in value.

The enemy advances and the land of Tecumseh's people shrinks. Furious at the loss of his settlement, he rallies the territories beyond his borders, appealing to those who settle for inaction – and who, should he fall, will be next in line.
The future holds only victory for those who continue to fight.
Differences must be set aside for the greater good.

City states watch as great powers face off on the battlefield, unsure whether they should remain on the sidelines or risk everything by getting involved. But Tecumseh, ever vigilant, will make that choice for them.
Bolster Military actions require less Influence.
Promote Growth actions require less Influence.
Civilians cower as warriors loot their homes. But when they move to take the innocents captive, Tecumseh raises a hand.

The warriors cry victory as enemies fall before their fury. Once again, Tecumseh's strategy has succeeded. Emboldened by their leader, the Shawnees melt into the landscape and prepare for their next attack.
A quick strike will quash the foe.
A hard blow is difficult to block.

A new Prophet rises from a death-like slumber. Shedding his old life, he relates a vision of a forked road, one path leading to joy, the other misery. He repeats the warning sent through him by the Master of Life: some evils cannot be redeemed, but the future may yet be saved. Tecumseh listens closely to the Prophet's words. Then, extending a hand, he helps his brother to his feet.
As enemies flee into the surrounding wilderness, Tecumseh's warriors celebrate their victory. Voices rise and fall around the campfires, sharing battlefield tales and imagining a new tomorrow.
Only through unity can enemies be overcome.
Strangers wander the streets, peering at unfamiliar sights and marvelous goods. But not for long – Tecumseh's people know how to welcome new faces and make them old friends.
Become Suzerain of an Independent Power.
The people may interpret this vision as they will.

Two lines of warriors face one another, lit by the sacred fire blazing in the night. Together they cheer for coming battle. But Tecumseh's gaze is suddenly drawn away from his army, towards the fire. Silence falls as a serpent emerges from the flames. As it rushes away into the darkness, the shouts pick up once more, louder than ever.
The Vision reveals the path to victory.
Craftspeople carve images of serpents, and children draw those long bodies in the soil. All know the snake's appearance from the fire was a sign of victory.
How does a creature survive such heat?
Gentle wisps rise from the tomahawk pipe as Tecumseh draws its smoke into his lungs. The smoldering kinnikinnick promises new beginnings through friendship and union. But who should benefit?
The pipe itself is a gift worthy of alliance.
Tecumseh's tomahawk pipe passes from one friendly hand to another. New friendships have been made here, strong alliances to weather future storms.
Have an Alliance with another Civilization.

Stargazers point to the heavens as a comet streaks across the sky. Turning to Tecumseh, they see the celestial panther reflected in his eyes, pouncing through the stars. With a swell of pride, he watches his namesake disappear with a trail of fire.
The next hunt will be fruitful.

After much debate, local chiefs refuse to join Tecumseh's confederacy. Weary of arguing, they proffer a peace pipe to smooth over any ill will. Tecumseh, displeased with the lack of progress, holds the pipe carefully between his fingers. Then, in a single motion, he snaps it in half and tosses the fragments into the fire. "Again?" one chief sighs as his warriors urge him to reconsider. "Very well..."
Chiefs have become wary of Tecumseh's attempts at unification. Two city states are enough, they say leave the people to their own fates, and their own decisions!
{1_reward}, but lower all Independent Power relationships by 2.

Tecumseh's armies march the land, removing foes and making safe the lives of citizens. Though war continues, the union of his people lends Tecumseh strength, just as his leadership bolsters their bonds with each other.
The enemy's capital falls before the united army. In every street, they shout their victory, a single word emerging from so many mouths: Tecumseh!
Many join Tecumseh's cause every day, flooding through his gates and sending missives from afar. But more seek his guidance as the world's turmoil grows.
Tecumseh watches his people thrive – many nations in one, each a piece of the Prophet's vision realized. New horizons await, but the Master of Life's guiding hand will light the way.

As the two chiefs confirm their mutual allegiance, Tecumseh receives a symbol of honor and friendship – a sash directly from the uniform of his new ally. The item is valuable, but the gesture beyond price.
Display the sash for all to see.
Regift the sash to another ally.
The land grows crowded with buildings, and the natural world shrinks in the face of the metropolis. So much has been claimed. But to Tecumseh, the land remains for all.
Nature still has many gifts to offer.
The earth must be experienced in peace.

Tecumseh regards the artifacts before him. They sit inert, but in that silence he hears the voices of the past, the memories these objects have seen, the stories they could tell. They are the voices of humanity.

In the high era of Shawnee rule, it was the elders of the Cilakofe division who made the political decisions for the people. But under a {1_civilization_adj} government, their role is unclear. Some {2_civilizations_adj} Shawnee feel they no longer need to obey the old ways, others see the value in tradition.
{1_reward} in Cities for each Slotted Shawnee Tradition.
The new Shawnee take up new forms of governance.

The Cilakofe Elders, now a political party operating within the {1_civilization_adj} government, raise a concern over hunting grounds - long important to Shawnee. New urban encroachments threaten to deplete wildlife range.

{1_civilization_adj} Shawnee youth have rediscovered the teachings of Tenskwatawa. Long removed from the traditional authority of their elders, young Shawnee find themselves interpreting them on their own, rethought and revised for the modern age.
The youth return to the stomp grounds.
Shawnee songs are heard on the radio.
A Shawnee city planner unveils plans for new industrial zones, but Chillicothe elders are concerned that they will damage a centuries-old Mawaskawe Skote site.
Take the counsel of the elders.
Deny the counsel of the elders.
A new era requires new stories, and historians have begun with a vast treatise of the {1_civilization_adj} people. Shawnee Hoceepkileni wonder to what extent their stories will feature in the volume.
Hoceepkileni keep their stories in their community.
Hoceepkileni open their archives and contribute.
